Reporting Regressions

Running a regression (or multiple regressions) produces a lot of information — estimated OLS coefficients, hypothesis tests, goodness of fit measures, F-tests, the distribution of residuals, etc. The standard Base R output of the lm() object using summary() looks like this:

library(tidyverse)  # for mpg dataset
lm(hwy ~ displ, data = mpg) %>%
  summary()

Call:
lm(formula = hwy ~ displ, data = mpg)

Residuals:
    Min      1Q  Median      3Q     Max 
-7.1039 -2.1646 -0.2242  2.0589 15.0105 

Coefficients:
            Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)    
(Intercept)  35.6977     0.7204   49.55   <2e-16 ***
displ        -3.5306     0.1945  -18.15   <2e-16 ***
---
Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1

Residual standard error: 3.836 on 232 degrees of freedom
Multiple R-squared:  0.5868,    Adjusted R-squared:  0.585 
F-statistic: 329.5 on 1 and 232 DF,  p-value: < 2.2e-16

This contains:

  1. The model in formula notation (call)
  2. A five-number summary of the distribution of residuals
  3. A table of

    • Estimate and Std. Error for each OLS Coefficient (here, for (Intercept), \((\hat{\beta_0})\) and displ \((\hat{\beta_1})\)

    • Report of test statistic (t value) and p-value (Pr(>|t|) for two sided t-test of \(H_0: \beta_j = 0\) for each \(\beta_j\)

    • Indicators of statistical significance at \(\alpha\) levels of 0.10 (*), 0.05 (**), and 0.01 (***)

  4. Goodness of fit measures

    • Standard error of the regression Residual standard error

    • R-squared and Adjusted R-squared

    • All-F test
